meta.title: Blue March 2026 • Banc d'Arguin National Park • Mauritania
meta.description: Blue March – 2nd edition: From February 1st to 8th, 2026, 6 days of walking in the Banc d'Arguin National Park in Mauritania, blending coastal hiking, art, mental health, and environment. Join a unique human, artistic, and ecological adventure.

experience.title: A Unique Global Experience
experience.intro1: The Blue March is a citizen, artistic, and ecological initiative led by the ÂME Foundation and the Mauritanian Environmental Association (AME). A collective walk along the coasts of a UNESCO World Heritage park, connecting art & culture, mental health, and environment.
experience.intro2:
Protecting the ocean, wetlands, and biodiversity,
while taking care of our mental health.
experience.pillar1_desc: 6 days of walking along lagoons, bays, beaches, and islands of the Banc d'Arguin National Park, meeting the Imraguen communities and coastal ecosystems.
experience.pillar2_desc: Kites, visual arts workshops, recycled plastic exhibition, promotion of local crafts and poetic narratives of the desert and ocean.
experience.pillar3_desc: Presence of a medical team and cardiologists, talking circles and roundtables about mental health, stress, and social connection.
experience.pillar4_desc: Awareness of biodiversity, desertification, and climate issues in the Sahel. Concrete field actions and connection with the Tambass reserve projects.
experience.pillar5_desc: Crossings in traditional lancha boats, traditional Imraguen lancha race, lunch-conference on Tidra Island, opening and closing ceremonies celebrating the Park's fiftieth anniversary (1976-2026), symbolic tree planting and end-of-march concert.

gallery.title: In Pictures
gallery.intro: From golden dunes to turquoise lagoons, from Imraguen villages to bivouacs under the stars: relive the highlights of the first edition and immerse yourself in the exceptional landscapes of the Banc d'Arguin National Park, UNESCO World Heritage site.

itinerary.title: The 2026 Itinerary
itinerary.intro1: A great coastal crossing from Cap Tagarit to Mamghar.
itinerary.intro2: Each day alternates between dunes, tidal flats, bays, and fishing villages, with an average of 15 km of walking per stage.
itinerary.arrival_activity1: Welcome of international participants in Nouakchott (arrivals recommended on January 30 and 31, pick-up upon arrival)
itinerary.arrival_activity4: Opening ceremony with authorities and local communities
itinerary.day1_activity1: Departure from Cap Tagarit, spectacular rocky cape with cliffs plunging into the ocean
itinerary.day1_activity2: Walk along the coast to Iwik
itinerary.day1_activity3: Arrival in Iwik, emblematic Imraguen village
itinerary.day2_activity2: Lunch on a dune overlooking the bay
itinerary.day4_activity1: Long beach and observation of migratory birds
itinerary.return_activity1: Collective return to Nouakchott on February 8
itinerary.return_activity2: Hotel night depending on return flights
itinerary.note: The final itinerary is confirmed after reconnaissance and according to tides. Some sections include crossings in traditional lancha boats, with the possibility of encountering dolphins and migratory birds, supervised by Imraguen guides.

practical.title: Practical Information 2026
practical.calendar_item1: January 30–31, 2026: arrival of international participants in Nouakchott, airport pickup and hotel night.
practical.calendar_item2: February 1st, 2026: collective departure to Banc d'Arguin, installation and opening ceremony.
practical.calendar_item3: February 2–7, 2026: 6 days of walking following the Cap Tagarit → Mamghar itinerary.
practical.calendar_item4: February 8, 2026: return to Nouakchott and return flights.
practical.profiles_p1: The Blue March brings together walkers from around the world and Mauritania, in good physical condition, capable of walking 15 km on average per day at a moderate pace. No competitive athletic level is required, but minimal preparation is recommended.
practical.profiles_p2: We seek diverse international and multicultural profiles: artists, athletes, students, doctors, researchers, scientists, NGO members, journalists, and local communities.
practical.included_item1: Internal transport between Nouakchott and the Park (round trip)
practical.included_item3: Accommodation in bivouac, tents, guesthouses, and ecolodges
practical.included_item5: Supervision by AME team, park guides, medical team
practical.included_item6: Workshops, roundtables, cultural and artistic activities
practical.excluded_item3: Personal equipment (hiking shoes, sleeping bag, water bottles, etc.)
practical.excluded_item4: Personal expenses and additional nights outside the program
practical.charter_intro: Each participant commits to respecting the Blue March Eco-responsible Charter:
practical.charter_item1: Zero single-use plastic during the march
practical.charter_item2: Systematic sorting and collection of waste throughout the route
practical.charter_item3: Strict respect for fauna, flora, and sacred sites
practical.charter_item4: Symbolic contribution to carbon offsetting through plantings at Tambass
practical.charter_item5: Attitude of kindness, listening, and mutual support within the group
practical.visa_text: Passports must have a minimum validity of six months for the visa. For all confirmed registrants, a group visa application procedure will be organized. Required documents will be requested by email after your application is validated.
practical.health_text: A medical team and cardiologists accompany the march. An emergency plan is coordinated with Mauritanian authorities and the Park administration. Participants must report any significant medical conditions in the registration form.

foundation.title: The ÂME Foundation & AME
foundation.p1: The ÂME Foundation, founded by filmmaker Abderrahmane Sissako, carries a holistic vision of human and social development. It connects three major axes: Art & Culture, Mental Health & Wellbeing, Environment & Society, to repair our connections with ourselves, with others, and with nature.
foundation.p2: The Mauritanian Environmental Association (AME) is its operational arm in Mauritania. It coordinates field projects in close connection with local communities, authorities, and technical partners. Together, they develop the Tambass reserve as a pilot site for agroecology, circular economy, community health, and ecotourism.
foundation.p3: The Blue March is the emblematic initiative of this vision: an annual march that brings together engaged art, mental health, and climate advocacy, with the ambition of becoming an essential international gathering by 2030.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.intro: Everything you need to know before embarking on the adventure.
faq.q1_question: What physical fitness level is required?
faq.q1_answer: The march requires good general physical condition: an average of 15 km per day on sandy terrain. The climate in February is pleasant, with temperatures between 16 and 28 degrees. Gradual preparation (regular walks, ankle and back strengthening) is highly recommended. Breaks are planned and the support team will be attentive to assist anyone experiencing temporary difficulties.
faq.q2_question: In what language does the march take place?
faq.q2_answer: The main working languages are French, Hassaniya, and Arabic, with support in English for international participants. Official events may be translated.
faq.q3_question: Can I come with my family or children?
faq.q3_answer: The Blue March is open to adults. Young people aged 16 and over can participate if accompanied by a participating parent. Shorter, family-friendly formats may be considered for future editions.
faq.q4_answer: Applications are reviewed by the coordination team, ensuring diversity of profiles (gender, age, geographical origin, areas of expertise) and motivation. Special attention is given to people who can contribute to group dynamics and advocacy after the march.
faq.q5_question: How can I support without walking?
faq.q5_answer: You can become a partner or donor of the Blue March and the Tambass reserve, share our content, organize echo events (screenings, symbolic marches, workshops) or offer media support. Use the form above by choosing "Partner / sponsor" or "Other".
faq.q6_question: When will I receive complete practical details?
faq.q6_answer: After your application is validated, you will receive a participant kit with a detailed equipment list, travel conditions, health advice, updated visa procedure, and emergency contacts. A WhatsApp communication group will also be created to facilitate exchanges between participants.

map.waypoint_cap_tagarit: Spectacular rocky cape in the heart of Banc d'Arguin. Known for its cliffs plunging into the water and desert landscapes. Starting point of our crossing.
map.waypoint_iwik: ~15 km - Emblematic Imraguen village. Crossings in traditional lancha boats with the possibility of encountering dolphins and migratory birds.
map.waypoint_tessot: ~15 km - Walk along lagoons and beaches. Bivouac installation by the sea.
map.waypoint_serenni: ~15 km - Walk between dunes and lagoons. Observation of the park's exceptional marine biodiversity.
map.waypoint_techot: ~15 km - Stage paced by the tides. Meeting with Imraguen fishing communities.
map.waypoint_rgueiba: ~15 km - Prime area for observing migratory birds and marine wildlife.
map.waypoint_awguej: ~15 km - Famous for its exceptional biodiversity. Crossing wetlands rich in marine and avian life.
map.waypoint_mamghar: ~15 km - Final stage of our coastal crossing. Closing ceremony celebrating 50 years of PNBA.
